content.text: Measure the length \(l\), the width \(w\) and the height \(h\) of the stack of slides in centimetres to the nearest millimetre
Do **not** remove any slides from the stack
Use the balance provided to measure the mass \(M\) of the stack of slides to the nearest \(0.1 \text{g}\)
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the glass. Use your results from **(a)** and **(b)**(i) and the equation shown
Give the unit for your answer

parts.label: (i)

content.text: Use your answer to **(b)(i)** and information from the card in **(c)** to estimate the number of microscope slides \(N_{1}\) in the stack of slides

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Use your answer to **(a)** and information from the card in **(c)** to obtain another estimate of the number of microscope slides \(N_{2}\) in the stack of slides

content.text: The mass \(m\) and the thickness \(t\) of a single microscope slide are written on the piece of card
Write down the values of \(m\) and \(t\) that are on the card
Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10\%\) of each other
State whether your values of \(N_{1}\) and \(N_{2}\) from **(c)(i)** and **(c)(ii)** can be considered equal
Support your statement with a calculation
calculation
Suggest one reason why the estimated values of \(N\) may be different
In this experiment, you will take measurements of a stack of glass microscope slides to estimate the number of slides in the stack
Fig. 1.1 shows the stack of slides

As the resistance between terminals P and Q changes, the current in the circuit changes

Use your results in Table 2.1 to write a conclusion, stating how the change in current affects the voltmeter reading \(V_{\mathrm{QR}}\) across the LED and the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{LED}}\) of the LED
A student attempts to set up the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1. The student finds that when the switch is closed, the LED does not light up
Suggest what the student may have done incorrectly while setting up the circuit
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a light-emitting diode (LED) when the current in it changes
The supervisor has set up the circuit as shown in Fig. 2.1
Switch on the lamp
Place the lens at a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object (the triangular hole in the card)
Adjust the position of the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen
Measure, to the nearest \(0.1 \text{cm}\), the image distance \(v\) from the centre of the lens to the screen
Record the image distance \(v\) in the top row of Table 3.1
The diagram in Fig. 3.2 shows the illuminated object
illuminated object
In the space below the illuminated object, draw a diagram to show how the image that you observe on the screen compares with the object
Calculate the magnification \(m\) of the image using the equation shown
Repeat the procedure in (a) for values of \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 35.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 45.0 \text{cm}\), \(u = 55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(u = 60.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot a graph of \(\nu /\mathrm{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(u / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis)
Draw the best-fit curve
Use your graph to find the value of \(\nu\) when \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
Use the values of \(u\) and \(v\) from **(e)** to calculate the focal length of the lens
State one technique you use when doing the experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is as clearly focussed as possible
In this experiment, you will investigate the image formed by a converging lens
Refer to Fig. 3.1
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate at which the water cools depends upon the diameter of the water surface exposed to the air
You are provided with:
· a supply of hot water
· a set of glass beakers of different sizes
· a measuring cylinder
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus
You are **not** required to do this investigation
In your plan, include:
· any other apparatus needed
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate
· the key variables you will control
· a results table to record your measurements (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· how you will process your results to draw a conclusion
You may include a labelled diagram if you wish
